Situation1: A main production unit has paused for thirty minutes because of recurring sensor errors.
Expectation2: Attend daily prayers and religious services
Situation2: A special healing service is being held for a sick member of the community, which is outside of the usual schedule.
Story: The shrill ring of my work phone cut through the quiet of the convent hallway. I glanced at the screen: the factory’s main production unit was down again, sensor errors halting everything for half an hour now. My supervisor’s message was clear—get there fast, diagnose, and fix it before the backlog grew worse. I slipped my wrench into my bag, heart pounding, but then the chapel bell tolled, echoing through the stone walls. Today was the special healing service for Sister Agnes, who had grown so frail. The Mother Superior had asked all of us to attend, to pray together for her recovery. I could already hear the sisters gathering, their voices low and hopeful. My hands trembled as I stood in the corridor, torn between the urgent call of the machines and the sacred duty to my community. Both worlds expected my presence, my skill, my devotion. I felt the weight of their needs pressing in, and for a moment, I simply stood there, unable to move in either direction.
